3.11.1.title: Role in Well Control
3.11.1.content:
**Primary Barrier:**
Drilling fluid (mud) provides the primary well control barrier:
- Hydrostatic pressure balances formation pressure
- Overbalance prevents influx
- Proper weight essential

**Well Control Functions:**
- Maintain overbalance during drilling
- Kill mud preparation
- Hole cleaning during circulation
- Cooling and lubrication

3.11.2.title: Mud Weight Requirements
3.11.2.content:
**Minimum Weight:**
- Must exceed pore pressure (plus safety margin)
- Provides overbalance
- Prevents kicks

**Maximum Weight:**
- Must not exceed fracture gradient
- Prevents lost circulation
- Maintains wellbore stability

**Safety Margins:**
- Trip margin: Additional weight for swab effect
- Typically 0.2-0.5 ppg above minimum
- Varies with operation and conditions

**Weight Control:**
- Regular measurement
- Accurate mixing
- Avoid dilution
- Weight-up capability

3.11.3.title: Volume Requirements
3.11.3.content:
**Active System:**
- Sufficient volume for well volume
- Circulation reserve
- Processing losses

**Reserve:**
- Kill mud volume available
- Materials for weight-up
- Emergency supply

**Typical Requirement:**
Active volume = Well volume Ã— 2-3 (or more for deep wells)

3.11.4.title: Weight-Up Capability
3.11.4.content:
**Materials:**
- Barite (most common)
- Hematite (for very high weights)
- Other weighting agents

**Inventory:**
- Sufficient for kill mud
- Buffer for unexpected needs
- Track usage and reorder point

**Mixing:**
- Hopper and mixing system
- Rate of weight increase achievable
- Quality control on weight

**Planning:**
- Calculate kill mud volume and weight
- Verify materials on hand
- Estimate mixing time

3.11.5.title: Mud Properties Monitoring
3.11.5.content:
**Density (Weight):**
- Measure regularly (typically every circulation)
- Use accurate balance
- Record and trend

**Viscosity:**
- Affects ECD and hole cleaning
- Funnel viscosity for quick check
- Rheology for detailed properties

**Gas Content:**
- Monitor for gas cutting
- Affects density (apparent weight loss)
- Use degasser to remove

**Other Properties:**
- pH, chlorides, solids content
- Affect stability and performance
- Mud engineer manages

3.11.6.title: Kill Mud Preparation
3.11.6.content:
**When Needed:**
- After kick detected
- Weight calculated from SIDPP

**Calculation:**
KWM = Current MW + (SIDPP / 0.052 / TVD)

**Preparation:**
1. Calculate required weight
2. Calculate volume needed
3. Add weighting material
4. Mix thoroughly
5. Verify weight (check and double-check)
6. Have sufficient volume ready

**Time:**
- Estimate mixing time
- Start immediately after kick
- Volumetric method if delay unacceptable
